repnme.cdata!: FYR Macedonia - Deepening the reform agenda

abstracts.cdata!:
The Former Yugoslav Republic (FYR) of
            Macedonia is located on one of the most important European
            international routes - corridor X - which link Europe with
            Greece, Turkey, and Central Asia. The efficient and
            effective operation of the regional road and railway links
            is important to the country’s growth potential. Through the
            Railways Reforms Project, the previously inefficient and
            non-profitable state-owned enterprise has been transformed
            into two more accountable and transparent companies that are
            increasingly adopting a commercial approach to their
            operations as they implement new business plans. To deepen
            the reform process, the World Bank and the government have
            agreed on a detailed set of actions that are now being
            implemented. The successful completion of these actions
            should result in a financially viable railway transportation
            system able to compete for a fair share of available traffic.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Railways Reform Project
            for Macedonia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: planning for slow implementation of
            institutional reforms. Implementation of complex reforms
            takes time and the project timeline should have accommodated
            possible delays with decision making. Maintaining regular
            policy dialogue is therefore key to success. Combining
            institutional reform and investments under the same project.
            Careful consideration should be given whether to combine
            physical investments with institutional reform of the
            sector. In many cases, such combination would be prone to
            significant delays and unsatisfactory implementation due to
            the fact that institutional reform is a lengthy and
            politically sensitive process and many factors could
            influence the pace of reforms. Comprehensive analysis of
            financial and operating performance is critical for
            successful monitoring of railways projects. A recommendation
            for future railway projects would be to pay special
            attention to consistent interpretation and recording of
            project indicators, particularly when the team composition changes.

repnme.cdata!: Reforming the rails in FYR Macedonia

abstracts.cdata!:
In order to establish the regulatory
            framework for a market with more than one operator,
            Jankulovski’s Infrastructure Company published a network
            statement describing the transport services available, the
            characteristics of the railway network, the level of track
            access charge, and conditions for contracting transport
            services. In essence, the joint effort of the two Macedonian
            Railways companies, the Ministry of Transport and
            Communications, and the World Bank team, has turned the
            previously inefficient, closed, and non-profitable
            state-owned enterprise into companies that are now more
            accountable and transparent. And they are increasingly
            adopting a commercial approach to operations as they
            implement newly developed business plans. The challenge now
            facing the government and the railway companies is to
            safeguard and deepen the reform process. This will require
            full implementation of the legislative and regulatory
            framework, and rehabilitation of critical sections of
            corridor ten. Remaining steps are to increase safety and
            operating speeds, and for the government to fully compensate
            rail operators for passenger services they request. These
            steps are necessary for a financially viable railway system
            which is an essential element of the Former Yugoslav
            Republic of Macedonia's economic and social development
            as a member of the European Union.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Railways Reform Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Railways Reform
            Project for Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of will
            improve the financial viability, productivity, and
            effectiveness of railway operations. The extension is
            necessary to allow: (i) delivery to the Macedonian railways
            transport Joint Stock Company (JSC)-Skopje of the 25 flat
            bed wagons being supplied by the company Gredelj prior to
            project closing and the full disbursement of funds. The
            wagons are currently under construction but complete
            delivery and acceptance is not possible before the current
            closing dates of the loans. The Borrower has in place an
            action plan to ensure delivery within the proposed closing
            dates and this is being monitored by a Ministerial Committee
            comprising members from the Ministry of Transport and
            Communication, the railway company and an independent
            expert; and (ii) carrying out of the second set of
            measurements needed for the calibration of the railway
            information management system being installed for the Public
            Enterprise (PE) Macedonian railways infrastructure-Skopje.
            The first set of measurements are about to be completed and
            a six month gap is required between the first and second
            measurements for technical reasons. The Borrower has in
            place an action plan to ensure that the second measurements,
            over a two week period, takes place by mid-March, 2011. This
            will be the second extension of the initially agreed project
            closing date of October, 2009.

repnme.cdata!: Macedonian railways - Deepening the reform agenda

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            deepening the reform agenda in Macedonian Railways.
            Macedonian Railways, which operates the country’s railways,
            was in the mid-1990s one of the largest loss-making
            companies among Macedonia’s public sector enterprises. Its
            operational performance was declining and was unable to pay
            staff salaries. Railway Reform Project, financed by World
            Bank, progressively transformed the single Macedonia
            railways into two new market oriented companies, set up the
            conditions for use of the railway infrastructure by other
            operators, and established the regulatory framework for a
            multiple operator market. World Bank has supported the
            country in its transition to a market economy and in
            building effective institutions, improving education, social
            protection and pensions, building and rehabilitating basic
            transport and energy infrastructure, and preserving its
            natural and cultural heritage.
